no, file permissions go by UID not by username
there are sideeffects however. Think about vyrious configuration files in ~/ or installed software and filesystem permissions (e.g. /usr/local/)
a new username (Unix user) gets new IDS 1000+x
which is why what you're saying results in more file permission problems
if you keep your UID and just change the name attached to it, you dont have to go around and chown everything
so they why are you saying that making a new username will make *fewer* complications?
I say that because the user has to migrate manually and then can make appropriate changes in configuration and permissions. Maybe I expected to much though. :-)
yeah see the extra manual changes sounds like "more work"
indeed it is more work but you break less than by *just* changing the user and *then* breaking parts of the system (causing lock-outs, etc.)
as long as those 3 files are in agreement, nothing should break
that's only right for fs permissions in case the UID stays 1000 *and* when configurations paths in ~/* are updated or use $HOME (which some don't).
configuration paths in ~/ ?? they should all be using $HOME and besides that, the directory in /home/ does not need to match the username
